title: Huawei Plans Extensive Layoffs in the U.S. in Wake of Blacklisting
summary: Cuts are expected to affect workers at U.S.-based R&D subsidiary Futurewei Technologies. Huawei Technologies Co. is planning extensive layoffs at its U.S. operations, according to people familiar with the matter, as the Chinese technology giant continues to struggle with its American blacklisting.

title: Puerto Rico Governor Facing More Pressure Following Leaked Texts
summary: Some political allies withdraw support for Gov. Ricardo Rosselló as protesters demand his resignation. The administration of Puerto Rico Gov. Ricardo Rosselló was engulfed in crisis as top officials resigned and political allies in the U.S. territory withdrew their support after a trove of private messages were leaked.

title: Making Sense of Djokovic and Federer's Brilliant Madness
summary: Excitable thoughts after a five-hour, five-set epic-and that newfangled tiebreak format-at Wimbledon. Wimbledon, England

title: Kamala Harris Makes Case Against Trump at Brooklyn Fundraiser
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has said he would support former Vice President Joe Biden but so far hasn't made many visible moves. The line to enter a fundraiser for U.S. Sen. Kamala Harris stretched around a sweltering block in Williamsburg last Wednesday night, as the former California prosecutor became the latest Democratic presidential hopeful to expand her beachhead in New York.

title: Manufacturers Move Supply Chains Out of China
summary: Tariff costs prompt executives to shift production to other countries; 'Once you move, you don't go back'. U.S. manufacturers are shifting production to countries outside of China as trade tensions between the world's two biggest economies stretch into a second year.

title: Mexico's Economy Falters as U.S. Chugs Along
summary: The Latin American country's slip toward recession marks the first time in 25 years the neighbors' economic cycles have sharply diverged. MEXICO CITY-Mexico is slipping toward a recession even as the U.S. economy continues to grow, the first time in 25 years that the neighbors' economic cycles have fallen sharply out of sync.

title: Barry Mostly Spares Metro New Orleans, Flood Risk Remains
summary: Forecasters warn of heavy rainfall in other parts of Louisiana and the lower Mississippi Valley. NEW ORLEANS-Barry, the first hurricane of the 2019 season to hit the U.S. coast, largely spared metro New Orleans. By Sunday afternoon, the slow-moving storm was downgraded to a tropical depression as it headed north.

title: Power Utility Searches for Cause of Massive Manhattan Blackout
summary: Engineers need at least several days to determine the cause, but cyber and terrorist attacks have been ruled out. Engineers spent Sunday examining power equipment to root out the cause of a massive outage that plunged a swath of Manhattan into darkness a day earlier.

title: Iran and U.K. Talk Over Tanker Crisis
summary: The countries' top diplomats discussed the matter of the seized Iranian oil tanker on a call. The U.K. and Iran sought to defuse tensions over a detained Iranian oil tanker in the British overseas territory of Gibraltar, but failed to resolve an issue that has raised new fears about military conflict over commercial-shipping lanes.

title: Erdogan Takes Putin Over NATO
summary: Turkey's president tests the alliance by buying Russia's air-defense system.. Turkey has begun taking delivery of the S-400 air-defense missile system from Russia, despite U.S. warnings about potential sanctions. The U.S. and NATO don't have much choice now other than to rethink whether Turkey still belongs in the alliance.

title: To Kill a Federal Program
summary: Job Corps lives on, despite poor results and unsafe campuses.. Ronald Reagan famously quipped that the closest thing to eternal life is a government program. Witness the Trump Administration's recent resuscitation of job-training centers despite manifest failures and assaults against participants.

title: Now It's a Climate 'Emergency'
summary: Democrats are ready to use Trump's precedent for their own purposes.. When President Trump declared a national "emergency" in February to take money from the Pentagon to build his border wall, these columns warned he was setting a precedent that Democrats would exploit. Well, that day has arrived, as Democrats last week introduced a resolution in Congress declaring a national emergency due to climate change.

title: Lessons From a Trip to the Moon
summary: Fifty years ago, Apollo 11 demonstrated both the perils and promise of innovation.. "It's a 1202. What is that?"

title: Mexico Loses a Check on Corruption
summary: The finance minister resigns in objection to AMLO's assaults on the rule of law.. The Mexican peso fell almost 2% Tuesday after Finance Minister Carlos Urzúa announced he was quitting his job. The shock waves roiling the financial markets were due as much to the contents of Mr. Urzúa's resignation letter as its suddenness.

title: Abortion Politics Crosses the Border
summary: Suddenly Canada's debate sounds a lot like America's.. Canada has a new import from its southern neighbor: abortion politics. Canadian theaters are screening the American movie "Unplanned"-a dramatization of a true story about a Planned Parenthood employee who became an antiabortion activist-and the governing Liberal Party isn't happy about it.

title: 'Bletchley Park and D-Day' Review: Clearing the Fog of War
summary: Bletchley's intelligence ensured the success of the invasion, but its job was far from over with the Normandy landings.. The success of the British code-breakers at Bletchley Park during World War II has become legendary. The technological challenges they faced were huge. Racing against the clock, men and women like Mavis Batey, Dilly Knox and Alan Turing took messages intercepted by Allied intelligence and looked for ways to decrypt the German Enigma codes-which changed daily and Adolf Hitler believed to be unbreakable. Many books have been written about Bletchley, but none has focused exclusively on the significance of its work for D-Day.

title: Disorder Rises in de Blasio's New York
summary: Graffiti and petty crime are rampant again, as the mayor denies the justice system's legitimacy.. New York

title: Call Iran's Bluff With an Offer of Nuclear Power
summary: No enrichment, but other countries could supply the fuel rods for the peaceful production of energy.. The Iranian regime recently announced its decision to produce fissile material with a purity of more than 4.5%. Iran's nuclear program is again on the march. In truth, it never stopped-contrary to glowing media reports and efforts by some Western leaders to spin on what the regime was doing.

title: Stick to the Public Option, Democrats
summary: It's the best way of making sure everyone has coverage without the radical step of tearing up existing plans.. Commentators have focused on the aggressive health-care agendas of Democratic candidates like Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren. Yet of the 20 candidates in last month's debates, only four said they favored single payer, or Medicare for All. The rest favored a public option-a better approach.

title: Kavanaugh Fight Was No 'Win'
summary: The left savaged a man's reputation and America's institutions-and paid no price for its indecency.. When the Senate confirmed Brett Kavanaugh 50-48, it was a victory over American politics' most vicious smear campaign in decades. Or was it? The left failed to keep Judge Kavanaugh off the Supreme Court, but it did irrevocable damage to his reputation and to America's institutions-for which it has paid no price.

title: Democratic Candidates Clash Over Health Care
summary: Biden, Sanders fight over whether to shore up Affordable Care Act or move to Medicare for All system. PHILADELPHIA-The health-care debate among Democratic candidates is intensifying, with Joe Biden and Sen. Bernie Sanders fighting over whether to shore up the Affordable Care Act or to move to a government-run health plan.

title: Gilead to Boost Stake in Belgian Biotech Galapagos as Part of $5.1 Billion Deal
summary: Gilead to get rights outside Europe to Belgian company's treatments in development. Gilead Sciences Inc. will pay $5.1 billion to boost its stake in Galapagos NV and gain rights outside Europe to the Belgian biotechnology company's treatments in development, in a broad research collaboration aimed at increasing growth at the drugmakers.

title: Economy Week Ahead: China GDP; U.S. Retail Sales and Housing Starts
summary: University of Michigan consumer-sentiment data will also be released. In the week ahead, China will release GDP data and the U.S. will publish fresh retail sales, housing starts and consumer sentiment figures.

title: Israelis Clash Over Bus Service on the Sabbath
summary: A Tel Aviv suburb works through its own version of a political dispute over religious observance. RAMAT GAN, Israel-Mayor Carmel Shama-Hacohen's desk is strewn with evidence of the threats against his life over his campaign to introduce public bus service on the Sabbath-an effort that put him on one side of a broader dispute that some call a battle for the soul of Israel.

title: Which $15 Wage CBO Figure Do You Trust?
summary: The CBO projection of job losses from a $15 minimum wage is in a range from zero up to 3.7 million.. Regarding Michael Saltsman's "How Many Jobs Would $15 Minimum Kill?" (op-ed, July 9): Democrats normally cling to Congressional Budget Office projections like "deplorable" Trump voters cling to guns or Bibles, but one guesses that the CBO's median-scenario estimate of 1.3 million job losses resulting from a $15 minimum wage isn't one that they will latch onto. Mr. Saltsman mentions that the CBO's worst-case scenario is 3.7 million job losses, and the Journal's same-day "CBO Sees $15 Pay as Mixed Bag for Workers" (U.S. News) reports a CBO projection of zero job losses in a range up to 3.7 million. The spin for Democrats and many in the media will be that several million workers benefit from a $15 minimum wage and the CBO says that there is a chance that there will be no job losses.

title: Climate Change: A Financial Risk for Banks
summary: We at the Network for Greening the Financial System-the group of more than 40 central banks and supervisors-see climate change as a source of financial risk, meaning its management falls squarely within our mandates.. "Streetwise: Central Banks Take Risks in Climate-Change Steps" (Business & Finance, June 19) suggests central banks are stretching beyond their mandates when developing policies on climate change. I must strongly disagree. We at the Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS)-the group of more than 40 central banks and supervisors-see climate change as a source of financial risk, meaning its management falls squarely within our mandates.

title: Education Department Is Slack in Collection of Loans
summary: Let's demand the Education Department start negotiating settlements with students who are able to pay at least a portion of the debt owed.. Regarding "On the Unfairness of Forgiving Student Debt" (Letters, July 2): Before engaging in wholesale debt forgiveness of student loans, let's demand the Education Department start negotiating settlements with students who are able to pay at least a portion of the debt owed. This occurs frequently in private industry, where half a loaf is seen as better than no loaf. Contrary to common sense, the current policy at Education seems to be that no loaf is better than any portion of it.

title: Naive Millennials: Sheep in the Democrats' Abattoir
summary: The problem for the millennials is that they are far too brainwashed to think rationally about what any Democratic government will do to them.. Joseph Sternberg is spot on in "Bernie and Elizabeth Wage War on the Young" (Political Economics, July 5). The problem for the millennials is that they are far too brainwashed to think rationally about what any Democratic government will do to them. By the time they sober up and realize they have voluntarily impoverished themselves, the damage will have been done.

title: Trump Wisely Less Flexible
summary: I will try not to be 'more flexible' during my second term, like the last president.. Regarding your editorial "The Trump Doctrine" (July 1): President Trump should have responded to the press kerfuffle about his bringing up election interference with Russian President Vladimir Putin with: "I will try not to be 'more flexible' during my second term, like the last president."

title: Oxymoron Alert: Some 'High Yield' Bonds Go Negative
summary: For junk bonds that have negative yields, peculiar characteristics help explain their especially ultralow rates. summary: Resume Subscription. Back in the 1960s, every high-school science nerd knew that "laser" stood for "Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation."

title: The Agony of Hope Postponed, by a Value Investor
summary: The dire years have produced plenty of theories on why value hasn't worked of late. Value investors are known for being a hardy bunch, willing to buy into beaten-down stocks that everyone else thinks are a disaster. But cheap stocks have underperformed horribly over the past 12 years, and even some fund managers who specialize in buying them wonder in private if the technique no longer works. Could value be dead?

title: Boeing 737 MAX Grounding Could Stretch Into 2020
summary: Company executives, FAA engineers and regulators have expanded their safety analyses to cover a growing list of issues. Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX planes are unlikely to be ready to carry passengers again until 2020 because of the time it will take to fix flight-control software and complete other steps, an increasing number of government and industry officials say, even as the company strives to get its jet back into service this year.

title: Port Authority Fights Suit Over Renovation Delays
summary: George Washington Bridge Bus Station has store vacancies two years after project completed. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is battling a lawsuit brought by a contractor seeking $120 million over delays and cost overruns at the George Washington Bridge Bus Station in upper Manhattan.

title: As Banks Report Earnings, Fed Looks to Take Away the Punch Bowl
summary: Higher rates have been an engine for earnings. That is likely ending.. What goes up must come down.

title: New York City Homeless Shelters Get Warm Welcome
summary: Some residents have been organizing meet-and-greets with their new neighbors. The opening of a homeless shelter in New York City has at times led to local opposition, heated protests and even lawsuits. But some residents have taken a different tack, by welcoming shelters to their communities with open arms.

title: Scooters, Segways and Skates: Latest Vehicles Try to Solve Your Last-Mile Problem
summary: Nearly half of all car rides are less than 3 miles: Boosted Rev, OneWheel Pint are some cheaper, easier, even faster electric alternatives. You have a meeting in 15 minutes, 20 blocks away. Are you going to get there on time?

title: Venezuela Gives Colombian Rebels Free Rein
summary: Resume Subscription. LA YUCA, Colombia-At a small navy base here on the Arauca River, Colombian marines have erected camouflage screening so rebel snipers operating from across the river in Venezuela can't see them to pick them off.

title: For Decoding Labor Market, Unemployment Rate May Not Do the Job
summary: Wage growth has been muted and inflation weak, leading economists to come up with new measures of joblessness. The U.S. unemployment rate last month hit 3.7%-one of the lowest levels in half a century.

title: One Upside From This Year's Rain: Less Fertilizer and Algae in Lake Erie
summary: The pollutants that feed algae are washing into the lake at lower amounts.

title: At What Age Do You Meet Your Best Friend?
summary: The 20s, typically a time of important first experiences, are prime years for meeting your closest lifelong confidantes, researchers say. Rachel Collins met her best friend, Jen Corp, when she was 21.

title: Trump Faces Tough Challenge From Top Democratic Candidates in Election Matchup, WSJ/NBC News Poll Shows
summary: Joe Biden, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders show an edge over Trump in trial contests. Three of the top Democratic presidential candidates-former Vice President Joe Biden, Sen. Elizabeth Warren and Sen. Bernie Sanders-lead President Trump among voters nationally in test matchups, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll finds.

title: Disney Looks to Extend Box-Office Reign With 'Lion King'
summary: High proportion of adults plan to see remake without children, signaling broad appeal. LOS ANGELES- Walt Disney Co. appears poised to stay atop the box-office food chain with "The Lion King."

title: Military Unit, Ravaged by War, Regroups to Survive the Peace
summary: Suicides drive Bravo Company veterans to test whether reuniting will help overcome lingering effects of battle. Nearly a year ago, the combat-hardened paratroopers of Bravo Company realized things were getting too dangerous. They weren't working as a team. Too many men were dying. Nobody seemed to know how to stop the bloodletting.

title: Trump Has Seen High Turnover Among Top White House Aides
summary: Turnover in high-profile positions has been higher than previous administrations. Only about one-third of President Trump's original top aides remain nearly 2½ years after he took office, according to an analysis of White House personnel data.

title: Beauty Brands Focus on Women of Color
summary: Customers with darker complexions are finding more makeup options, as startups and established brands follow Fenty Beauty by Rihanna in targeting an untapped market with inclusive offerings. When Brittany Williams started wearing makeup in her early 20s, she struggled to find products that matched her skin. The 29-year-old pharmacy technician said she is "darker-complexioned" and tried countless foundations, including one that made her "end up looking sort of orangey," due to its red undertones.

title: She Wants to Win at Pétanque More Than You Want to Win at Anything
summary: For one California player, the French game similar to bocce and lawn bowling is more obsession than leisure activity. Janice Bissonette realized her obsession with pétanque had reached a new level when she started practicing her throw-and-release motion while walking her two schnauzers. "The neighbors think I'm over-friendly, crazily waving as I go around the block," she says.

title: Power Returns After Widespread Outage in Manhattan Darkens Times Square
summary: Fire at electricity transformer blamed in outage affecting more than 62,000 customers. Power was slowly returning to parts of Manhattan Saturday night after a widespread outage plunged subway stations, stores and parts of Times Square into darkness.
